comments.text:
The whole idea that nothing can travel faster than the speed of light comes 
from Eistein's thought experiments about relativity, i.e.: the speed of 
light must always be c in every reference frame. So, no. The light would 
not be trapped in the flash light. From your point of view, it would appear 
to behave normally. For an outside observer, in order for the speed of 
light to remain c, your time would have to run backwards.

top_comment.text:
Gravity is stronger at the poles? Not sure I understand why that would be 
true...﻿
top_comment.author: superdupe8

comments.text:
i learned that the earth isnt a perfect sphere. and that the poles are 
supposed to have more gravity because it is closer to the core than the 
equator. of course, many factors exist. sorry im using my ipad and i cannot 
think well.
comments.author: Erica Cho

comments.text:
+superdupe8 It's a mix of 2 causes: 

1.- The rotation of the earth creates a slight centrifugal force that 
cancels out a tiny bit of gravity, making it to appear weaker.

2.- This centrifugal force creates a bulge of matter on the equator, making 
things there further apart from the core in comparison to the poles. Since 
gravity depends squarely on distance, this gives a lower strength.
comments.author: Chris Jaquez

comments.text:
+superdupe8 Basically, the faster you're spinning (which depends on where 
you are on the planet), the less you will weigh.
comments.author: Derek Z

comments.text:
+Lukas Nordlund "This spinning creates a force that pulls away the earth", 
Can you elaborate what that means? The magnitude of gravity for a single 
object is determined by the mass of the object and it's radius. I would 
assume that earth's radius is roughly the same for any point on it's 
surface. You're saying that gravity is changing because of different 
velocities on different points of earth's surface? That's not an increase 
or decrease in gravity, it's an increase or decrease in the centrifugal 
force.
comments.author: superdupe8

comments.text:
If you spin a globe, you would see that the poles don't really spin much at

and that also makes the gravity less

comments.text:
Well, as the mass of a celestial body increases, you get to a point to 
where atoms at the core are so pressurized that nuclear fusion starts to 
occur, and that is the driving force that makes a star a star. Overall this 
has more to do with mass and density than just volume, so that's also 
largely dependent on the composition of the planet. If we are to consider 
the extremes, such as a planet that's extraordinarily large but also made 
of particularly light materials and a star that's extraordinarily small but 
nonetheless has enough mass to be a star, you could potentially get a 
'normal' planet that has a larger volume than the smallest 'normal' star, 
but I'm not sure.

I don't think there's any general scientific consensus on what it is, but 
what could decide when a planet becomes a star would depend on a mass 
threshold, how massive a celestial body must be before nuclear fusion 
starts to occur at the core. Jupiter is nowhere near this threshold, even 
though its composition is similar to what a star's would be, and we have 
found planets 10 times the size of Jupiter (planets larger than this are 
debated over whether they are planets or brown dwarfs) that obviously 
aren't stars. The mass threshold is also likely dependent on the 
composition of the body in question, as an overabundance of heavy elements 
I believe makes nuclear fusion more difficult, but most gas giants are 
comprised almost entirely of hydrogen and helium, the most common elements.

There are celestial bodies that fall just within or just short of the mass 
threshold for internal fusion, and become the aforementioned brown dwarfs. 
They're not really considered stars as enough combustion occurs for the 
dwarf to radiate some energy, but does not have stable internal fusion. 
Since they're not really considered planets either, they're sort of a class 
of their own.

The conclusion I draw from the scientific debate whether the extrasolar 
planet almost 30 times more massive than Jupiter is a brown dwarf (most 
massive planet discovered) is that if you go a bit further, you get a 
full-fledged star. Perhaps when a body is about 85-90 times more massive 
than Jupiter (the upper limit of brown dwarfs' mass is 75-80, so beyond 
that point they achieve sufficient internal fusion to be a main sequence 
star)? It would still be a very small and cool star, but it would be 
considered a main sequence star. Even then it would be nowhere near the 
size of the sun either in volume or mass, so I would say it's impossible 
for a planet to be the size of the sun.

comments.text:
1. Any time an object moves in a circular path it is because centripetal 
force acts on it. Centripetal force is what pulls the moving object towards 
the centre of the arc. Gravity is acting as the centripetal force in this 
situation 2. The centripetal force is subtracted because that amount of 
force is required to keep you in the arc and not fly outward. This is what 
is required to cancel the 'centrafugal force'. Centrafugal force is the 
apparent outward force cause by inertia outward in tangent line. (it is not 
really a force)
comments.author: Everett Sass

comments.text:
Yeah stupid may or may not be the right word, but you are quite wrong in my 
opinion... 
What you didn't get : 
1- Gravity isn't a force, it's the interaction of two masses that causes 
them to attract each other... In this particular case the Earth and the 
people that live on it. The attraction force that results from this 
interaction is a centripetal one (to our planet). 
(Please excuse my english if it's bad or not exact, I'm just trying to 
explain the idea behind Michael's words) 
2- About the substraction stuff... If you listen to the entire sentence you 
get :"The centripetal force required to keep you along a cirular path with 
Earth is substracted to the Earth's total gravitational pull on you". And 
this in my opinion means "The gravtiational pull that the Earth has on you, 
is enough to make you stay close to the Earth and follow the circular path 
that we have around it". After that he teaches us that the result of this 
substraction is how much we weigh, it's the remaining force we measure with 
a balance.

top_comment.text:
Question, let's pretend you are flying in a plane for at least 24hrs and 
that you are no longer in contact with earth's surface, are you still 
spinning at the earth's velocity or do you have a different velocity than 
earth? Explain anyone?﻿
top_comment.author: FalkonX3000

comments.text:
Depends, if you are flying in the earths direction of rotation when it 
stopped, you would have your plains velocity added to the spin of the 
earth, and it's the opposite for the other direction.
comments.author: GuiltyMiner0343

comments.text:
I would assume that It depends on the direction you are flying. Let's say 
you are flying against its rotation at 368 m/s. Technically speaking, you 
are suspended in place (not factoring in earth's orbit around the sun). If 
you were to stop flying in this direction, your momentum would carry you a 
bit further and eventually, air friction would slow your speed until you 
are falling straight down. Then, you are no longer going against Earth's 
rotation, rather you are going with it, and once again will be travelling 
as any other "still" object is. If you were to continue at 368 m/s for 24 
hours, against Earth's rotation, the time of day would not change. I'm no 
scientist though, this was all my guess.

comments.text:
+Jamie Green
Through the history of man kind we verify everything we learn and we 
discover factual rules (e.g. laws of physics). each rule has its own 
conditions and specifications that we use to know if its applicable to 
different objects or not. (e.g. to check if "fluids dynamics" apply to an 
object, we need to verify if its fluid!). And we use our senses (regardless 
of tools and technology) to collect those conditions and specs about any 
object. so:
Rule -> Collect Specs -> Does the Rule apply? -> Yes/No -> Conclusion

comments.text:
+Steve Fox If you don't know my age, how can you tell me that you're 5 
years older than me? I'm not a teen but, yes, we are both still learning. I 
know how to respect the power of the Internet and how to treat it, yet I 
have much to learn. I am 11 and I'm above average than most kids my age and 
grade. Yes, I am still a kid and far from my teenage years. No, I don't 
know a lot of things. There are more things I don't know than actually 
know. Be prepared for a very long comment, and I might get off track:

I, like probably 99% of the Internet, are about under aged (for this kind 
of account), but I don't go on Twitter or Facebook or Instagram. I don't 
share my personal info, except my first name and state (no one can actually 
hint you down if they have no gear with your first name and state because 
we all share names). My mom knows what I am on and knows what I am doing. 
If I did something bad, I wouldn't be able to get on it. I am mature enough 
to know what to say and what not to say, for example these little kids 
calling everyone "gay" as an insult when it's ignorant. Gay means happy and 
there's completely *nothing* wrong with homos or "gays." I don't do that. 
It's okay for an opinion, but as long as you don't offend anyone bad 
(offending is still not okay, but it depends on the person and how they 
take it). I don't cyber-bully, I don't share picture of my food (seriously, 
why do people still do that? We know what food looks like...), I don't do 
drugs, I don't smoke, and I definitely don't crush up Smarties and snort 
them (you know who you are **cough** 12 year olds on my bus **cough**). I 
don't do that. I don't act like I'm some drug addict teen. I don't go on

and yes, I am ignorant to a lot of things. I don't take selfies of myself, 
and I don't pretend to be someone I'm not. I don't make fake account with a 
random name and my profile picture an emo selfie I found on the Internet. 
Please forgive me if I offended anyone.

Why is there more gravity at the poles? If the earth is a spheroid you 
would expect higher gravity at the equator. If it's a sphere you would 
expect evenly distributed gravity.﻿
top_comment.author: Rubashow

comments.text:
+Arthur Vandelay He is aware of that. The gravity enacted upon them is not 
the same as it is for us. This is the crux of this conversation. I wasn't 
sure why the water would be pulled towards the poles as stated in the 
video. It would be, because the gravity increases the more you move into 
earths gravitational well.
comments.author: Rubashow

comments.text:
+9Asfaloth9
Almost -- Astronauts orbiting the Earth in the space station have apparent 
weightlessness not because the force of gravity is so much weaker but 
because they are in a continuous free-fall and don't have any normal force 
pushing against them.  One way you can check this is to plug in the 
distance the space station is from Earth into Newton's law of gravitation 
and see that the gravity they feel is almost the same as it is for us.
comments.author: Arthur Vandelay

comments.text: Ahh. That makes sense. Thanks.
comments.author: Rubashow

comments.text:
+Rubashow The poles are closer to the center of the earth and 
therefore have more pull. It's also the reason why the force of gravity is 
(slightly) weaker on high peaks, like Mt. Everest, for example. Or barely 
felt on shuttles orbiting the Earth.
comments.author: 9Asfaloth9

comments.text:
The bulge at the eqator is exactly the reason why gravity is stronger 
there, provided the earth isn't rotating. The diameter of the earth at the 
equator is larger than the distance from pole to pole. That is why there is 
more pull.
comments.author: Rubashow

comments.text:
Due to the bulge at the equator, the poles have more gravitational force.

The Earths Gravitational pull is much greater than the rate that the earth 
spins (Which pulls outward). Everything with weight effected by the

from earth. So it doesnt matter how much you weigh... it matters how close 
you are to the earth and how fast the earth is spinning.

+AwesomeVindicator The Earth's rotation is gradually slowing, but it's due 
to tidal interactions with the Moon. The Earth-Moon distance is slowly 
increasing, and the angular momentum of the Earth's spin is slowly being 
transferred to the Moon. (Ref.

comments.text:
Well, being flung forward, or in any direction is just really you 
continuing moving in a direction while the Earth stops. You'll keep moving 
until something stops you, say a wall, sliding on the ground, or air 
resistance, which will happen on Earth. The basic escape velocity to escape 
a spherical object is Ve=(Square root) 2GM divided by r. G is the 
gravitational constant and M is of course the objects mass. Earths escape 
velocity is 11.2 km/s. In reality, we all are, in a way, floating, as the 
Earth is in a free fall around the Sun, at an angle. Again, regardless of 
mass, the pull of gravity is the same, if nothing gets in the way of the 
fall, and distance remains the same, as gravity gets weaker with distance. 
Sorry for the long comment, can't explain things shortly. :)

comments.text:
Any object, regardless of mass, falls at the same speed. Assuming the two 
objects, let's say a bowling ball and feather, are dropped at the same 
height, they will both hit the ground at the same time, if there was no air 
friction, as the bowling ball is more aerodynamic. A ping pong ball and 
bowling will hit the ground at the same time if dropped from the same 
height with air friction though. :)

comments.author: trellbfieldArts _

comments.text:
i think this will answer your question, cause no one else is answering it 
differently 

a feather would weigh a lot less if the earth supposedly lowers its 
gravity, but so would the air around the feather, as EVERYTHING is affected 
by the decrease in gravity. in order for something to float up, it has to 
be lighter than the air around it, such as a balloon. A balloon is filled 
with helium, a lighter gas compared to the heavier oxygen and nitrogen 
around it. the balloon floats up, while everything else "sinks" towards the 
ground. so that means that (with very very little gravity) the feather 
would still sink because the air around it would still be lighter (until 
the air leaves the earth because of the lack of gravity)

comments.text:
The date and time has been kept by various authorities since around 45Bc, 
original by Julius Caesar with the Julian Calendar which was then reformed 
in the 1500's to our current Gregorian calendar.

The authoritative bodies that kept these records continued without being 
destroyed or otherwise greatly damaged since that period and our current 
year is based on those authorities agreed year of the birth of Jesus. So we 
are quite sure that this is is the 2014th year since the agreed upon birth 
of Jesus (it may not be the year he actually was born, but it has been 2014 
since the year it is believed he did).

Our current usage of years and time has nothing to do with anything before 
that time period so anything before then has no effect on our measurements.

Technically it's possible some error occurred and was covered up or 
forgotten, but it's also possible blue unicorns are using magic to hide 
under the earth's surface waiting for our moment of weakness to jump out 
and kill us all. But like with the time/date, I don't think it's very 
likely. :P

This may sound like a stupid question, but does light react at all to 
gravity? If you were to fire a super powerful laser at chest level going 
straight, would it make it around the globe and hit you in the back or 
would it shoot off into space?﻿
top_comment.author: legoC97

comments.text:
light reacts to gravity but not dramatically enough for your scenario to 
occur. it curves around planets, black holes, and other supermassive 
objects with high levels of gravity (see "gravitational lensing"). if light 
were as sensitive to gravity as your question proposed then light would 
never leave the sun. it'd be trapped circling around it and we'd never be 
able to see anything! haha and that would make me a very sad camper

But doesn't time not exist? If you were to go deep out to space to a point 
where you can't see anything what time is there?  Wouldn't that make time 
irrelevant?  I believe time is just a reference we use to measure how long 
we've past/spent here.  If you go out far enough and we look like a star 
all we are is just a point of infinite change.  So even though we are all 
existing at the same time, everything that was meant to happen will happen 
we just need to go through the motions.  If you were to come to a fork in 
the road you, no matter what you pick you were meant to pick it. Yeah I 
went on a little rant, but what do you think?﻿

comments.text:
Half of the mainstream scientific community suggests that time is an 
illusion meanwhile the other half maintains that it is not. Most however, 
agree that we'll know more concretely within the next decade or so. The 
surprising thing is that mathematics as we currently understand it, allows 
for time to be nonexistent. However, the laws of thermodynamics - 
specifically entropy points towards the existence of an "arrow of time" 
which flows only in one direction. For now, which you believe is ultimately 
up to you. I myself, am on the fence of that issue.

comments.text:
Superman flies by combining three of his abilities. Earth's gravitational 
pull is weaker the that of Krypton, so superman would theoretically have 
the same mass and strength but less weight. However, he is super strong. 
Additionally, he (and all Kryptonians) generate a bio electric aura-like 
field around himself. Superman's lesser weight and super strength allows 
him to leap tall buildings in a single bound, while his electric field 
polarizes to be suspended in the magnetic field of the earth, extending bus 
ability so he flies. This explains why he can change direction, rather than 
going in a straight parabola like jumping would do. Some evidence for this 
theory is in the movie Man of Steel, when superman is shown kneeled before 
he takes off, the rocks around his fist pressed to the ground are seen 
floating, almost telekinetically, showing that it is not just Superman's 
corporeal form, but a small area of effect around him.

center. That is because the Gravitational Potential Force measures the

comments.text:
+KiwiPowerNZ
Right, the cables with less bounces are known as single-mode fiber and have 
to be ran in as straight a line as possible. Usually single-mode cables are 
yellow and multi-mode are orange. Though my point wasn't to imply the 
internet is as fast as light to be clear. Especiallly when you count the 
latency for routers and other networking hardware (and your computer) add 
to the equasion. It is pretty amazing that I can reach California (from 
Michigan) in about 50ms, but light itself would only take ~1ms (as the crow 
flies provided I didn't fudge the calculation)

comments.text:
+Dunbar Sloane The pure glass core in fiber optics is not hollow. The light 
passes through the glass and bounces off the cladding around the glass like 
a mirror. The thinner the core the less bounces and the longer the range of 
the cable.

comments.author: Anton Jansson

comments.text:
Fiber optic cables which connect us to the internet use total internal 
reflection of light inside the thin fiber optic tubes to bounce beams of 
light through them. The light takes slightly longer to get to it's 
destination because of the added distance it has to travel with the 
reflection from the internal walls of the cable and the slightly slower 
speed that light has when travelling through the medium of air as opposed 
to a vacuum which is the proper 'speed of light.'

comments.text:
+SS52 To be more contructive, here is a specific criticism of the site: on 
the page on gravity, you calculate the speed of the ISS by multiplying its 
total time in orbit by its acceleration. However, your calculation is 
incorrect because you treat the velocity and acceleration as scalar 
quatities, when in fact they are vector quantities (they have magnitude and 
direction). The acceleration in question is always perpendicular to the 
velocity of the ISS. The result is that the acceleration changes the 
velocity of the ISS by constantly changing its direction, but not its 
magnitude (i.e. speed).

comments.text:
Just in case it hasn't been said already (too many posts to read them all) 
- to calculate the future, you need to do two things: Get a 'snapshot' of 
the current state on the smallest scale of particles and detect the 
properties of every such particle. 

Any higher level calculation will not work cause you'd be missing vital 
data. 

Problem is you cannot do both simultaneously on the required scale. You 
either know where something is or where it's going but never both at the 
same time.

So while interesting to think about - actually calculating the future is 
physically impossible.

+Lillestoel Great deep thinking, but free will doesn't really exist.

Watch the VSauce video "What is Random?". You will see that all processes 
in the universe are governed by quantum fluctuations which are completely 
and purely random. These processes control the atoms which make up our 
physical world, from our bodies to every outside stimulus we perceive, and 
therefore influence our lives through sheer chance. The staggering 
complexity of all these uncountable processes that make up our brain cells 
and cause our actions creates only the illusion of free will, when in 
reality all our actions are ultimately decided by probability and can be 
said to be preordained.

That's the gist of it on the quantum level. But for our everyday purposes, 
we must ignore this fact and embrace our ignorance of the deepest workings 
of nature. So I guess an amended version of my argument could be "free will 
exists, but is at its heart the product of unpredictable quantum events 
which we have no control over."

comments.text:
(If any part is croosed out, it's Youtube's action - It's worth the same 
and it makes sense altogether)

ANSWER TO YOUR QUESTION: First of all, quantum physics. That is about 
possibilities. But since I am not an expert on it, I'll tell you what I 
"think" I "know":

Let's say we discover everything. What atoms are made of to the last level, 
etc. Every particle. Everything. Let's say the universe is not infinite, so 
that we can process all that data (process infinite seems just... never 
ending). We are already assuming that the universe is not infinite, and we 
are forgetting about quantum physics too. Well, even then, you have another 
problem. You didn't measure everything from the beginning. And that means 
that everything that will happen since you start measuring will be affected 
in an unknown way by all those things that happened before. Probably.
An example? Maybe you can measure to death the trunk of a tree. The way it 
is, its condition (suffered X damaged, in these points, etc. -you know, to 
the smallest particle). But human minds? I don't know. First because we see 
someone. We like that person. Then the wind is 9.8m/s, so we feel it. We 
scratch for a combination of elements/reasons, and smile. Then maybe you 
think you already forgot those unimportant things, when all of a sudden 
something happens and it reminds you of that moment. Maybe it was a 
subconscious process. Well, that factor is going to affect the outcome. And 
sometimes, it's one of the most important factors. The product was great, 
but your nose reminded me of a person I had an argument with, so I turned 
it down. For example.

Yet maybe it's possible to know everything about our brain so that, even if 
we don't know part of the data, we can say how our brain will react. Well, 
then you face at least two last problems. First of all, maybe you can find 
the smallest element on earth/universe (beyond "God's particle/s", etc.). 
But what about time? The word infinite sucks. But you can divide 1 second 
into infinite parts, and in every of those, something is supposed to 
happen. Maybe. So that you cannot measure anything because you need the 
data of the instant called: Static infinite part of a second. And you will 
never end dividing it. 

But now think that things do not happen so instantly, but instead they take 
some time. I don't know, but let's say things jump from instants to other 
instants that are bigger than 1s/infinite. And let's assume the outcomes 
are always the same. A cell always "does the same things" no matter what. 
Because if that factor that changed the outcome changes its state at 
smaller intervals than the one it takes for cells, we may be screwed.
But even assuming you can find that one thing that changes fastest on earth 
(universe, actually), that you measure its changes if necessary, and all of 
everything else, and so you can predict things- let's call it predict-, 
there is ONE LAST THING:

-HOW CAN YOU BE SURE ABOUT IT? HOW CAN YOU BE CERTAIN THAT THERE IS NOTHING 
YOU ARE MISSING? I WILL USE THE WORD MAYBE, BUT MY "ANSWER" (yes, without 
analyzing it much) IS PRETTY MUCH YOU CAN'T. SO YOU COULD PREDICT FUTURE, 
AND DO IT RIGHT, BECAUSE LET'S SAY YOU FOUND EVERYTHING THAT IS AND "CAN 
BE" ON EARTH/UNIVERSE, EVERY POSSIBLE NEW FORM OF LIFE ETC. ALRIGHT. YOU 
GOT IT. YOU'D BE PREDICTING THE FUTURE! BUT YOU COULDN'T TRUST IT BECAUSE 
YOU WOULDN'T KNOW IF YOU WERE ACTUALLY CONSIDERING EVERYTHING.
WE THINK A LAW WORKS, BUT WHAT IF UNDER CERTAIN CONDITIONS IT WORKED 
OTHERWISE? HOW CAN YOU TELL IF YOU DON'T KNOW THOSE CONDITIONS? THEY'RE 
INFINITE. MAYBE. AND APART FROM THAT, THE MAIN POINT IS THAT YOU DON'T KNOW 
IF THAT'S ALL. YOU NEVER KNOW. BELIEVING SO IS JUST FAITH. DOESN'T MATTER 
IF YOU FOUND 100 LAWS OR 1 000 000 000 000 000 000. IT DOESN'T MATTER IF 
EVERYTHING FITS. MAYBE THE FORMULA IS OK, BUT IT NEEDED A SECOND ELEMENT TO 
CONSIDER AN UNCONSIDERED "AND VERY RARE" CONDITION.

And I didn't even talk about delays. Like light. When you see it, it 
"already happened" (let's not make it longer :)). That moment was gone. But 
even if you measure it according to your own "space/time" in the place you 
are (infinite too, probably; due to little variations due to changes in 
time due to mass, attraction, different posititions...) is that still 
predicting the future?

And one last thing. What about that thing that time for you, moving at a 
near-to-the-speed-of-light speed, is not the same as for me, in terms of 
outcomes? (getting older...)

BUT THE MAIN THINK FOR ME, AS I SAID, IS JUST NOT BEING ABLE TO PROVE THAT 
YOU ARE FACTORING EVERYTHING IN. EVEN IF YOU ARE DOING SO, THAT DOESN'T 
MEAN YOU CAN BE SURE. IT'S FRUSTRATING, AND BEAUTIFUL. "LIKE THE COMMENT I 
WROTE" :)

AND I DIDN'T MENTIONED MUCH ABOUT PARADOXES!...

Oh, can anyone please tell me the exact number of words I used? Apparently, 
the more I write, the less I think, the older I get, the less smart I 
become, and the more irrelevant it is for you, the more you will like it 
and feel like doing it. So you tell me. I bet you will.

comments.text:
Global warming and ice age stuff are incredibly complex. I will try to 
simplify and give a few main reasons:
- the most important thing to note is a positive feedback loop: if the 
Earth warms a bit, that leads to warming even more. That is mostly because 
ice melts and the Earth is a bit darker, thus reflecting less sunlight.
- tectonic plates move. If a continent is on top of a pole (as one is now), 
or if an ocean it at a pole and walled off (as one is now, lol), it is 
harder for heat to get transfered all across the planet, which turns out to 
cool the planet down.
- the Earth's orbit around the Sun is changing slowly. Sometimes we are 
closer, sometimes we are further away. The rotation axis is also wobbling 
around, making 1 cycle about every 30000 years (which is very often 
compared to the other things I've said).
- water is the most important greenhouse gas. The more of it is in the 
atmosphere, the warmer it gets. Small changes in temperature (for example, 
due to the CO2 we release) allow the atmosphere to be able to hold more 
water, which makes it warmer, which allows it to hold more water ... yup, 
it's just another positive feedback loop.

top_comment.text: Why does the sound pitch increase in a video when it is sped up?﻿
top_comment.author: john ramirez

comments.text: No problem. :)
comments.author: Jacob Baird

comments.text: O now it makes sense thanks
comments.author: john ramirez

comments.text:
I'll try to put this in my own words as best as possible, but keep in mind 
that I only know basic physics. But, I'll try to answer your question to 
the greatest of my capabilities.
I think you and I could both agree that the pitch of a sound is just the 
frequency of "pressure fluctuations" per every second, and the higher a 
frequency, the higher the pitch, so if there are 360 "fluctuations" in a 6 
seconds clip, then the frequency will in turn be 60 Hz (360/6=60). We can 
also agree that as a clip speeds up, less time has gone by between the time 
that the video or sound clip has started, and the time it has ended, so if 
a clip is running at twice its regular speed, then there is less time, but 
the number of "fluctuations" stays the same. So, if there are, again, 360 
"fluctuations" in a clip, which this time lasts only 3 seconds, then the 
frequency will then become 120 Hz (360/3=120), meaning a higher frequency, 
which is a higher pitch. We can also do the opposite, there slowing a clip 
down decreases its pitch. So, in conclusion:
-A pitch is determined by its sound wave's frequency,
-A sound wave's frequency is determined by the number of "fluctuations" per 
every second,
-Speeding up the clip will reduce the number of seconds in the clip, but 
the number of "fluctuations" remains the same,
. . . and finally,
-This in turn means that speeding up the clip will increase the pitch.
Hope that helped!

Ok theists, especially those who consider creation "science", I have a 
question for you to explain. 
Joshua 10:13 - "And the sun stood still, and the moon stopped, until the 
nation took vengeance on their enemies. Is this not written in the Book of 
Jashar? The sun stopped in the midst of heaven and did not hurry to set for 
about a whole day." (English Standard Version)
Now all the "versions" are pretty much saying the same thing. The sun and 
moon stopped in the sky. For that to happen, the Earth has to stop 
spinning. The video shows us what happens when the Earth stops mid rotation.

pseudo science, call Ken and Ray, give us a decent scientific answer.

2:36 "The sun would seem to freeze in the sky as days become not 24 hours 
long, but 365 days long" -- I disagree. If the sun were to stay in the sky 
for a whole year long (granted you were on the side where the sun was 
shining), that would just mean the earth is tidally locked with the sun. 
And tidal locking still requires the earth to spin. Just as the moon is 
tidal locked with earth, the "bright side" of the moon is always facing us 
(same concept if we were to see the sun frozen in the sky). If the earth 
were to stop spinning, but still revolving around the sun, wouldn't 
sunshine only last half of the duration of the revolution (182.5 days)? One 
side of earth would get sunshine for 182.5, and then the other half would 
get sunshine for 182.5 days while the other side is dark in the mean time?﻿
top_comment.author: thehookupcupid

comments.text: Yeah, thought so too.
comments.author: Dｅmｏnｉtｅ

comments.text: Exactly. Thank you.
comments.author: Frox Dox

comments.text:
+Frox Dox Also, if you look at the revolution cycle, Earth takes 1 year to 
fully revolve around the sun. So, if it wasn't rotating while it was 
revolving around the sun, you would expect sunlight on one region to only 
last for half a year. (Try revolving a ball or anything on a certain spot 
without spinning, you'll see where I'm coming from)
comments.author: thehookupcupid

comments.text:

comments.text:

a day at all in this scenario would be insensible.

comments.text:
Pat. Try flipping a coin in an airplane while it's moving at 500 miles per 
hour.

You will notice the coin behaves exactly the same as if you were standing. 
Why? Why doesn't the coin fly to the back of the airplane? (hint: see The 
Principle of Relativity, and then you'll know why you feel like you're 
moving when you're sitting at a train track and a train is slowly moving 
next to you)

In any event, it turns out the size of the earth is so large that rate of 
change of your velocity when you jump is just about exactly the same as 
when you stand. In other words, the magnitude of the speed of the rotation 
of the earth is TINY in comparison to the magnitude of the circumference of 
the earth.

a = v^2/R

a is acceleration, v is velocity, and R is radius. 

The radius of the earth is so massive that the difference between square of 
the change in velocity divided by the radius of the earth when you stand 
versus the square of the velocity when you jump divided by the radius of 
the earth is approximately zero.

|v_standing^2/R - v_jumping^2/R| ≈ 0 

 That's why, brother.

+Zack Jones Gabriel was just saying we subconsciously access 100% of our

our brain to function and survive. If we even used 99% of it, we would die.

frontal cortex, which is responsible for all the things we say we only use 
10% of, we only use 10% because we do not, at least not at this point, need 
to use any more than 10% of it. The reason why other species use less than 
10% of their frontal cortex is because they do not need anymore than they 
already have to survive as a species. Look at how advanced we are with just 
10% brain power. Imagine how advanced we'd be with 15%? It's going to be a 
GIANT leap, because as you said, 6-7% used by other animals is very 
primitive compared to 10% of ours. What if we could use 100% of it? Well..

very primitive with 100% cognitive thought. Hell, we're already making 
hover cars and that's with 10%. I'd estimate with 20-25% power we could 
become immortal. We'd never die from old age.

no. This is because air is a fluid which is much thicker than most people 
ever realize. We are living on the very bottom of a literal "sea" of 
gasses. A vacuum doesn't have friction against anything because there is 
nothing in the vacuum. But there is loads of friction between the air and 
the surface of the earth. So the earth pushes the air around with itself. 
If a helicopter hovers still in the air, it will be still over one place on 
the ground and go nowhere. (assuming no wind)

comments.text:
You are pretty close but dreaming is actually the way the brain categorizes 
recent memories and saves the one it thinks is important and erases the 
ones that have no meaning, it also plays through different scenarios as 
sort of a way to protect itself. For instance if you have a nightmare your 
brain is actually mentally preparing itself for what it thinks might harm 
you and in term harm the brain itself, therefore if you seen something 
horrifying in your dreams then you will have a better idea how to react if 
it actually happen in the real world. The reason why when you think back 
and you have fond memories or even bad ones, when you think about them its 
kinda like a playlist of pictures not a streaming video, or try and sit 
back and think about what you did yesterday, you probably wont remember ,in 
great detail, tying you shoes, or how many times you changed the tv 
channel, or even what the first thing you said to your co worker or 
husband/wife. but wat you will remember is almost hitting that car on the 
freeway, or how many times you ate or probably even the exact item and 
amount of what you ate, because you safety and what you eat plus the amount 
are considered important by your brain and to help insure it and your own 
survival it flushes out the none important things. Or say if you almost had 
a wreck, you will probably have a dream about crashing your car that night, 
why? because your brain wants you to see what you did wrong and hope that 
if that situation ever did really occur that you would no how to change the 
outcome or do something different.

comments.text:
Alright, I guess I'll share my true, real opinion......Like Boro said, I 
see people picking on religion a lot, but people don't pick on 
science....What's up with that? Personally, I like to question BOTH. I 
think it's good to question and really think about what the Bible says. And 
really considering it before just jumping in and saying "Oh, this is what 
it says, ok I'll worship God, no questions asked!" However, this goes the 
same for science, as I refuse to mindlessly say "So this is what scientists 
are studying and what they say is true! Because I'm sure they know what 
they are doing!" No, I think it's best to question both. So my thoughts on 
God? Personally, I think there is no such holy being controlling us. And I 
just think, if he really was real and a good God, why does war and hunger 
and diseases still exist? I'm just saying. And science, I don't think all 
of it is true. What if they're lying? What if they don't know anything and 
are upset telling you what they want you to think? I agree with the guy 
above me, religion and science and exist together. But I think it's better 
to really think about what those two things are teaching you before 
suddenly believing it, no questions asked.

top_comment.text:
*You really should do an episode on the meaning of life. Not the 
philosophical meaning, but the scientific one*
But because the chances of you seeing this comment is so pathetically low 
and because I still want to share my opinion/thoughts on the matter I'll 
just do a discount take on it here. 

*What is the meaning of life?* 
What is the meaning of life, what is the meaning of our existence? This is 
a question we have all asked at least once or twice in our lives. We all 
also choose to answer it differently. 

Those whom want to live a comfortable life without pondering this 
fascinating question often goes to Religion for the answers. Not only does 
religion answer these questions but they mostly do so in warm ways that are 
typically not hard to understand and easily accepted by the ignorant 
fellow. However as time went on and education was offered to the average 
bloke these options became very unpopular and instead seen as primitive and 
dumb. 

So where do we go to get the answers now? Some people refuse to give up 
their religious beliefs but those who did went straight to Darwin's theory 
of evolution and natural selection which states that the purpose of life is 
to - for lack of better term - to fuck to keep life going. However this is 
unsatisfactory. There's just something about it that screams 
''INCOMPLETE!!!'' when you read about it. But up until now there has been 
nothing to add. 

*:WARNING: The following will be facts mixed with my thoughts and opinions 
built mostly during my time on the toilet* 
As Schrödinger demonstrated with his infamous ''undead'' cat experiment, 
observing nature forces it to arrange into something that fits within the 
physical rules of our universe. It all involves quantum mechanics which is 
rarely discussed because our brain is not outfitted with the tools 
necessary to logically understand it which is why I'll grossly simplify it 
for you guys sitting in your computer chairs presumably eating cheetos. 
Basically what's happening is that two fatass kids are trying to make it 
through a door to a room in which there is only enough space for one. But 
because they're so fat and because they're trying to make it through at the 
same time they instead get stuck in the door frame. That is until a third 
kid - representing the act of observing - helps them out by ramming them 
from behind. Forcing one through into the tiny room making the other fat 
kid search for a different door. 

Without the third kid the two kids would be stuck forever, trying every 
tiny variation possible within the space they're in. So in reality without 
the third kid, everything is possible. Which means every tiny variation is 
happening all at once which means that life is inevitable. Once life is 
created within one of these variations that means the act of observing is 
so also, which forces nature to straighten itself out and choose one 
specific variation, prompting the creation of a universe.

There are probably some faults in my logic that I'm sure some of you will 
point out but the ground work is stable. 
So according to me and the leading scientists within quantum mechanics the 
meaning of life is to keep the universe in check.﻿
top_comment.author: Dennis Persson

comments.text:
+MrSpeedyD3 Sorry that's not right.

On average, the atmosphere sort of moves with the earth, but at any 
particular point there is going to be wind (especially higher up).  But 
even without the wind, it still won't rotate with the earth.

When the helicopter is sitting on the surface, it has a certain amount of 
angular momentum such that it's moving along with the surface.  But if it 
flies straight up, the angular momentum must be conserved.  If angular 
momentum is conserved and if the altitude of the helicopter increases, it's 
angular velocity must decrease.  So without any atmosphere, it still 
wouldn't keep up with the earth's rotation.

But what about if we had an atmosphere with absolutely no wind (so the 
entire atmosphere is rotating perfectly along with the earth)?  Would that 
push the helicopter along enough to keep it stationary with respect to the 
earth?  The answer is still no.  Think about it this way.  If you drop an 
object off a tall building, does the stationary air below it keep the 
object from falling?  Of course not.  All it can do is slow the fall down. 
 Similarly, an atmosphere with no wind will help push the helicopter along 
a bit, but not enough to keep up with the earth.

So why are you able to throw a ball upwards and have it come straight back 
down?  The radius of the earth is 6300 km, so if you throw a ball 5 m in 
the air, it's distance from the center of the earth is only changing by 
0.07%, so it's angular velocity only has to change by 0.07%.  When the ball 
is only in the air for a few seconds, it can't fall behind very far.  A 
helicopter in the air for 12 hours should see this effect more clearly, 
especially if it flies higher.

comments.author: Dylan Thomas

comments.text:
Not really.

Yes, one requirement for an orbit is that it's 'outside' the atmosphere. 
 But it's more complicated than that.  You can choose the orbital height or 
the speed.  You can't choose both.  Low orbits are fast and high orbits are 
slow.  This is why it takes the ISS 90 minutes to complete an orbit, but it 
takes the moon 27 days.  Somewhere in between those two altitudes is an 
orbit which takes 24 hours.  This is the geostationary orbit.

Now technically there ARE an infinite number of orbits with a period of 24 
hours (these are called geosynchronous orbits.)  An object in a 
geosynchronous orbit might move across the sky but always return to the 
same point every 24 hours.  In order for an orbit to be truly 
geostationary, it must be geosynchronous, it must be circular, and it must 
be level with the equator.  These is only one such orbit.

Basically, no.  There is only one geostationary orbit.

comments.author: Nick C.

comments.text:
+Nick C. Well that wouldn't be hovering then.  They would have to 
counteract inertia.  When the helicopter starts out, it's sitting on the 
ground and the ground (being part of the Earth) is rotating at one 
revolution per day, as we know. Since the helicopter is also sitting on the 
ground, it's also inside this moving reference frame, and has the momentum 
that goes with it so the helicopter is also moving at one revolution per 
day. In fact, so is the air! Now, when the helicopter takes off, it flies 
straight up to some height above the Earth's surface. But though the 
helicopter has exerted a force (through the use of its rotors) to lift it 
straight up, it hasn't exerted a force in the horizontal direction to 
counter the motion (momentum) it already had that one revolution per 
minute! So though the helicopter is no longer touching the ground, unless 
the pilot purposely exerts a force against the helicopter's initial 
momentum, the helicopter will continue to move at one revolution per day, 
and thus remain above the same spot on the Earth's surface from where it 
took off. The momentum that the helicopter started with is the same as what 
it ends with that's conservation of momentum!
comments.author: Jamie Messier

could correct for the wind to hover over one spot.
comments.author: Nick C.

comments.text:
+Nick C. No.  He's saying it's not orbiting at all.  It's hovering.  
Completely different things.  The proverbial helicopter would actually be 
pushed by the atmosphere and cannot sit in one place.  This is due to a 
force called "wind" to make it simple.  Wind is caused by high pressure 
moving into low pressure or a force causing wind.  With the world rotating 
(force) and pressure changing (high -> low pressure), it would be 
impossible for a helicopter to not move with the planet.  Of course, that 
doesn't mean that it's going to stay in one place the whole time.  It may 
move from that spot very slightly.  But it will never hover above the Earth 
as still as it would if the Earth had stopped rotating.
comments.author: Jamie Messier

just in terms of going around at the same speed above the earth at a fixed 
point above the earth. Not technically, though.
comments.author: Nick C.

comments.text:
+Nick C. No.  In order for something to be in a geostationary orbit, it 
needs to have the same rotational velocity as the earth, and it needs to be 
in an orbiting.  A hovering helicopter is not orbiting.  Also, you can't 
have different heights of geostationary orbits.  If an object is in 
geostationary orbit, it's at 36,000 km, and if it's at 36,000 km it's in 
geostationary orbit.  Anything else is not geostationary.

comments.text:
This is a stupid belief based on a very old study from the very beginning 
of neurobiology.

They discovered that most of the brain's mass wasn't composed of neurons 
cores, so they tought most of the brain's mass was useless.

But actually, it turned out that the mass they considered not being neurons 
were axons, which are nerve fiber allowing neurons cores to transmit 
information to each other via synapses.

Basically, it's like telling that most of your computer space is unused 
because GPUs, CPUs and Memories ( ROM, RAM, HDD and SSD ) are only a few 
percent of its total mass, when the remaining mass is cables, connections 
and cooling.

comments.text:
With the Moon no longer there, the oceans of the world become much calmer. 
The Sun still has an effect on them (known as solar tides), so surfers 
wouldn’t be completely devoid of waves. But the oceans would largely become 
serene.

This has a dire effect on life on Earth. When life first formed on Earth in 
tidal pools, it was thanks to the gravitational pull of the Moon that 
primordial life was able to traverse between different pools and generally 
spread across the planet. While we’re already here now, life that is 
currently in the oceans is no longer able to move so easily. The churning 
of the oceans, and thus the circulation of nutrients, ceases. Water-based 
life struggles to survive and, eventually, thousands (and probably 
millions) of species go extinct.

The Moon isn’t done yet, though. You see, it also accounted for about 
one-eightieth of the Earth-Moon mass system. The loss of the Moon directly 
affects the Earth’s orbit, rotation and wobble. Without the Moon to act as 
a stabiliser, the Earth begins to wobble more and more, sending our seasons 
into turmoil and changing our orbit around the Sun from slightly elliptical 
to massively elliptical. We now swing around the Sun in a wild, unstable, 
fluctuating orbit.

comments.text:
Here's a simpler answer: The core is much, much more massive than the 
crust. Hence if you are closer to the center of the Earth, you will feel 
more gravity pulling you down. (Adding a mountain will only move you away 
from the center, and the mountain's mass is no match for the Earth's core.)
And the poles are closer to the center of the Earth due to its oblate 
spheroid shape.

This is the reason why you weigh less on top of the mountain than on the 
surface.
comments.author: Vince

comments.text:
+Kostas Giotis The largest mountain ranges on Earth do have a higher 
gravity than average, but there are also some parts of the oceans, such as 
the north atlantic ridge, with high gravity.

comments.text:
+MoRo1333 Centripetal force at the poles would be lesser than the 
centripetal at the equator. This is because centripetal force is 
proportional to the velocity of an object. Since we are moving faster at 
the equator, we require a larger centripetal force. This force is provided 
by the gravitational force of the Earth(which is assumed to be located at 
the center). Since we use up more gravitational force as centripetal force, 
there is lesser force providing us weight. Just a summary: There is only 
one force providing us with centripetal force and weight, which is 
gravity.If more force is used as centripetal force, there is less left for 
weight.
Therefore we weigh more at the poles.
comments.author: OfficialHuMan

ripped apart followed by a small splat of your remains.

fast enough you wont fall. But just jumping wont save you from bruises. So 
if you could jump and start running at Earth's rotational speed in your 
location BUT in the exact opposite direction... you'd still die from

comments.text:
+Musaka sadi Actually you are wrong, due to conservation of angular 
momentum, raising a building slows down the Earth spin because you are 
distributing the Earth's mass differently. For example, if you have a 
spinning sphere and shape it into an egg without adding or taking away any 
mass, you will still alter it's rotation because of alterations on its 
moment of inertia. Since angular momentum L is product between angular 
velocity and moment of inertia (and since the angular velocity is constant 
due to the fact that we're considering a constant speed rotation), and 
moment of Inertia is the definite integral from 0 to m (mass) of r squared 
(r being the distance of the outtermost particle of a body to its axis of 
rotation) in respect to mass, altering it's spacial distribution of mass, 
alters the value of the definite integral, and consequently angular 
momentum, resulting in a different rotational velocity. I guess "graduating 
grade 12 at age 16" isn't doing much for you.

comments.text:
Actually, that depends on what you mean by "spinning". The Earth would be 
spinning one way or the other, depending on what your frame of reference 
is. If you assume it is not spinning, that means one hemisphere is always 
pointing in one direction relative to some imaginary point in space, then 
day/night cycle would take 365 current days, with sunlight for 182 current 
days. In that case, the Earth would be spinning relative to the Sun.

Assuming the Earth is not spinning relative to the Sun, that is, one 
hemisphere would always be pointing towards the sun, the day/night cycle 
would cease to exist, because one hemisphere would be constantly in the 
daylight, while on the other there would be constant night. In that case 
though, the Earth would be spinning relative to the universe.

PS: Of course what we mean by "hemispheres" would change, since the axis of 
the Earth rotation is at an angle and not perpendicular to it's orbit.
comments.author: Xoruam

comments.author: Cloud Strife

comments.text:
Solar time is time measured with respect to the Sun's apparent motion in 
the sky. The clocks we use for civil timekeeping are based on this motion. 
Of course, the apparent motion of the Sun across the sky is actually caused 
by the rotation of the Earth. So, our clocks measure the length of time 
required for the Earth to rotate once with respect to the Sun. From our 
perspective, the Sun revolves around the Earth every 24 hours. This period 
is known as a solar day.

Sidereal time is time measured with respect to the apparent motion of the 
'fixed' stars in the sky due to the Earth's rotation. While the Earth is 
rotating on its axis it is also moving along its orbit around the Sun. Over 
the course of a day the Earth moves about one degree along its orbit (360 
degrees in a full orbit divided by 365.25 days in a year is about one 
degree). Therefore, from our perspective, the Sun moves about one degree 
from west to east with respect to the 'fixed' stars.

All of this means that according to our clocks, which are based on solar 
time, a given star will rise or set about four minutes earlier each day 
(the Earth rotates 15 degrees in one hour, i.e. 360/24, so one degree of 
rotation is equivalent to about four minutes of time). For example, a star 
that rises at 9:00pm (21:00) tonight will rise at 8:56 pm (20:56) tomorrow 
and at 8:52pm (20:52) the next night. One month later that star will rise 
or set two hours earlier. In other words, from our perspective, the stars 
revolve around the Earth in only 23 hours and 56 minutes. This period is 
known as a sidereal day.

We don't use the stars to dictate the time of day, but the sun.
comments.author: LordMatsu

comments.text:
+Skyler Thompson You are right, you are not an expert. Science and religion 
are absolutely not compatible. Science is based on observation and data 
collected through the scientific method, the single most successful 
methodology for verifying knowledge that the human mind has created. At its 
core is is the idea that the truth value of a hypothesis, theory, or 
concept is best determined by its ability to make falsifiable predictions 
that can be tested against an empirical reality, this means higher powers, 
spirits, demons or gods cannot be included in a hypothesis. Religion is 
based on faith and faith alone. You have no falsifiable evidence for your 
god, Yahweh, or any other god. No one possesses such evidence. 

You obviously know nothing about evolution, so allow me to introduce you to 
it. 

Evolution is change in the gene pool of a population from generation to 
generation by such processes as mutation, natural selection, and genetic 
drift. 

Natural selection is a simple tautology that should really be obvious.

Inheritance and selection:

If an inherited trait helps an animal or plant to survive and reproduce a 
higher percentage of organisms with that trait will survive and reproduce 
than the percentage without that trait. That is known as a favourable trait.

If an inherited trait makes it harder for an animal or plant to survive or 
reproduce a lower percentage of organisms with that trait will survive and 
reproduce than the percentage that survive without the trait. That is known 
as an unfavourable trait.

Over the generations the proportion of organisms with favourable traits 
will tend to increase while the proportion with unfavourable traits will 
tend to decrease.

Natural selection can happen in any situation where something reproduces 
and passes on its traits. Charles Darwin and Alfred Russell Wallace 
developed this idea independently. Natural selection affects the genes of 
living organisms.

Over time natural selection causes populations to differentiate as they 
adapt to new environments. Gradually new subspecies and new species are 
formed. This is known as the Theory of Evolution by natural selection.

comments.text:
Every single human on earth and every single human that ever lived. He did 
a part in a video which stated that if you put stacked every  human in the 
world in the grand canyon it would not even reach to the top of it. By 
comparison, Mount Everest stands at 29,026 feet (8,848 meters), meaning the 
deepest part of the Trench is 7,175 feet (2,186 meters) deeper than Everest 
is tall. Similarly, the Trench is 1,580 miles (2,542 kilometers) long — 
more than five times the length of the Grand Canyon. However, the trench is 
only 43 miles (69 km) wide.  The Mariana Trench which is the deepest point 
in the the world located in the pacific could hold all the bodies you throw 
all in the Pacific.

top_comment.author: Anthony Velarde

comments.text:
+Brandon Bravos I recently developed a theory on time. Here's how it goes: 
Assuming the Universe is alone, maybe if it is floating in time, there is a 
possible general speed. This "General Speed" is moving faster than time, 
sending us forward in time. By moving opposite the general speed, which may 
or may not exist on a different plane of existence, we would slow down 
through time. We'd still move faster than time though, so we'd just slow 
down. Moving with time would cause you to not move ahead of time, therefore 
stopping time for the object(s) moving with time. Moving slower would send 
you back in time. Moving faster than general speed would speed up time for 
the objects moving faster than general speed.
 
Again, this is just a theory. I merely thought it up randomly, so I have no 
factual evidence of any "General Speed".
comments.author: Max Alex Berndt

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Brandon Bravos That comment is funny because I actually do have a twin. 
And yes, the theory states that the faster you move, the slower you age. 
Therefore, you may be able to go back in time. But back onto the topic: At 
the speed of light, we'll be able to feel like you're going in regular 
time, but really time is slowing down around you. By the way, NASA 
scientists are working on something close to warp speed. But the energy it 
takes is alot, though I think by smashing atoms and using that energy, you 
would have more than enough.

captions.text: Hey, Vsauce. Michael here. The Earth is spinning

and we are spinning along with
it. But what if the

Earth suddenly stopped spinning? 
Well, first of all, you would
gain weight. But that would be the least
of your worries. The spin of our planet is important
and literally giving you the time of your life.
At the equator, the surface of Earth, and

everything on it, is spinning around at
465 meters per second.

As you move closer to the poles you
don't have to move as quickly to complete

Earths daily rotation. 
Here in San Francisco, the Earth is driving me

east at 368 meters per second. 
If I could float above the surface

independent of the Earth's rotation, the
Earth would spin underneath me

this quickly. Pretty cool. But, of course,
when I jump straight up into the air,

the Earth doesn't move underneath me
because I continued to spin with it.

We are all spinning with the Earth and
that is why slamming on a set of

magical planetary breaks that caused
everything

classically called earth to stop
spinning would be catastrophic.
Immediately everything that wasn't

Earth, and wasn't safely at the poles,
would continue moving, as it had been,

and be flung due east at more than a
thousand miles an hour.

You wouldn't be flung into space because
escape velocity is 24,800 mph
but your body would
instantly become a 9.5 inch caliber bullet.
Well, really more of a supersonic tumbleweed.

Because the atmosphere would more
gradually slow down, people in airplanes,

assuming they could navigate the
resulting storms, might have a better
chance of surviving.
Astronauts aboard the ISS would fare even better.
But it is unlikely that anyone would be waiting for them
down on the ground. Runways would just be
entrances to the new planet-sized graveyard,
created by the no longer spinning Earth.

People really really near the poles
might be okay but

only at first. Gusts of wind, as fast as
those near an atomic bomb detonation,

would blast, pass the surface and up into the
sky forming worldwide storms
of unprecedented magnitude. The friction alone,

caused by the now stopped Earth colliding
with these winds, would be enough to cause
massive fires,

unparalleled erosion and damage to
anything strong enough to stay put

after the initial braking. The Sun would
seem to freeze in the sky as days
became not 24 hours long but 365 days long.

Without spinning innards, Earth's
protective magnetic field would cease to exist

and we would be dosed with deadly
amounts of ionising radiation from the Sun.

The oceans would surge onto land in
tsunamis kilometers high and wash over nearly
all dry land, before migrating to the poles,

where gravity is stronger, no longer held to
the ocean basins by the inertia
Earth's spin gave them,

until Earth itself, no longer bulging an extra 42
kilometers around its equator, because
of its rotation
slowly compressed into a more perfect sphere

than it is now. Possibly allowing the
oceans to eventually return somewhat.
That is what would occur

if it actually happened.
It won't actually happen but
woah, its rotation is slowing down.

More on that later. First, if the Earth
really is spinning so quickly,
why can't we feel it? Why doesn't the Earth's rotation
make us dizzy? Well, lucky for us,

the change in velocity is just too
gradual. The Earth is too huge.
It's like driving in a car that takes

6 hours and six thousand miles to make
one

left turn. It's not sudden enough to
register
with our senses. But that change in velocity
is real and it makes us way

less, because of inertia. On our spinning
planet your velocity is constantly
changing but always

tangential to the circular path you were
being dragged along.

Now, because inertia is a property of
matter, which includes
your body, without a force acting upon us we would
slowly leave the surface of Earth.

Luckily, the Earth is exerting a force on us.
A center-seeking,
centripetal force, delivered by gravity.

The centripetal force required to keep
you along a circular path with Earth is subtracted
from Earth's total gravitational pull on you.
The remaining force simply pushes you down,
toward the centre of the Earth - it gives you weight.

At the equator, if the Earth didn't spin,
and no centripetal force was required to
keep you
with the Earth, you would weigh 0.3 percent
more than you currently do. If Earth spun you around

17 times faster than it currently does,
all of its gravitational force

would go toward centripetal force
fighting against your inertia
and you would be weightless.
So here's a diet idea. Hope that the Earth starts
spinning faster and go back for guilt-free seconds.
Seconds.
We know exactly how long
a second is. The outermost electron
of an atom of cesium 133 is alone.
When the atom is undisturbed, only the nucleus
interacts with this outermost electron, tickling it
regularly and rapidly between two levels.

oscillations between those two levels,
one second has passed.
Exactly.
That is literally the definition of a second.
We can measure and count those oscillations.
It's how atomic clocks work. Making atomic clocks,

the most accurate measurement device
ever built by humans, to measure anything.
We can't define
a second more simply, as say, 1/60th of 1/60th of 1/24th of a day
because of Earth's spin.
It's too irregular. Little changes

in the distribution of mass on Earth,
caused by earthquakes or melting ice
or man-made dams or technically
even you walking up stairs or downstairs,
cause Earth's rotational speed to change.

Like a figure skater moving their arms
further away from or closer to their bodies.
Now add on top of that the fact that tides, caused by the Moon,

drag against Earth's rotation and you
wind up with an
unstable rotation speed that is
predominately slowing down.

Now, these changes are incredibly incredibly
slight, but over time
they add up. In 140 million years,
a day on earth will not be 24 hours long,
it will be 25. That might not sound like much

but in order to do important things, like
deliver accurate GPS information,
we need a more accurate timekeeping device
than that. So, as a solution

scientists keep the pace of seconds
using atomic clocks,
TAI time. And other scientists

measure the changing speed of Earth's
rotation by observing distant stars

and quasars. Now, every few months they
find out just how behind or ahead

Earth is running, and if it's getting too
close to being a second

off, they decide to add or subtract the
second from the current year.
The result is the time used almost everywhere,
including your phone: UTC.
Since this system began in 1972
25 leap seconds have been added.
What this means is that clock time is,
and has to be, a manufactured
product with upgrades and tune ups administered
periodically, after defects
are noticed. The time we give to now
and the future is only ever
approximate. That's weird
but it's also entirely not weird.

As Demetrios Matsakis, the Chief
Scientist of Time Services for the US
Naval Observatory puts it,
"we save lives

and we end lives. We add time and we
can take time away,

but in both cases we do so
without completely
understanding exactly what life is,
or what time is."

Regardless, thank you for spending some
of yours with me...
and as always,
thanks for watching.

title: What If The Earth Stopped Spinning?
